snippet: Researchers put together most of a fetus’s genome using a mother’s blood and father’s saliva, heralding an era when parents might know much more about a child long before its birth.
abstract: Science Translational Medicine paper reports that researchers have been able to determine most of a fetus’s genome using a mother’s blood and father’s saliva, heralding an era when parents might know the complete DNA blueprint of a child months before it is born; such mapping, which would allow thousands of genetic diseases to be detected prenatally, would raise serious ethical considerations.
lead_paragraph: Researchers put together most of a fetus’s genome using a mother’s blood and father’s saliva, heralding an era when parents might know much more about a child long before its birth.
